reviews.review_text: DLC Quest is an amusing game that rightly pokes fun at the gaming industry while at the same time being a genuinely fun platformer.  The game is divided into two parts. First part is easy and won't really challenge too much, except maybe finding all the hidden items. The second part has a moderate challenge that adds wall-jumping (which Player must earn by getting the DLC), spikes and a hilarious ending. It's great to play a game that makes you laugh most of the way through. Also, for 100% achievement hunters, this game's list of achievements is short and reasonable.  Perhaps not worth full price since the playing time is about 3 hours, but recommended whenever on sale.  EDIT: changed 'The game is broken' to 'The game is divided' ...

CAUTION: This game is only actually worth it when it goes on sale because it is a short and easy game, but it still serves as fairly decent satire.  There really is not much I can say about the gameplay, replayability or graphics because the game doesn't need to look amazing considering it's puny length and you would already know what to expect from the gameplay. You cannot die, there's close to no physics and unlike the Stanley Parable; when you replay this game, you will get all the same things. However, this game does give an important message about DLC overkill in games. In most games, you will see pre-order bonuses, retailer exclusives, overpriced and stupid DLCs which don't really enhance the game so much as to justify the purchase of DLCs, they seem to serve as novelties nowadays.   This is what makes this game important. Remember the days around the PS2 era where if you bought a game, you got the whole game and not just parts of it which will be filled in with DLC. That made games more exciting and more worth paying for. That all changed with the dawn of expansion packs for the big MMOs and Horse Armour (I'm looking at you, Oblivion!) but it isn't entirely for the worst from what I have seen. The DLCs for Saints Row: The Third have added many hours to the game and are of decent quality rather than being lousy 20 minute long stories which I thought was cool.   The only real issue I have with the game is the fact that I, and many others already know that a lot of DLC is pointless on the PC unless a game doesn't have mod support and on PC, mod support is always expected and always demanded for it to constitute 'a real PC game' which is fair enough knowing that mods are changing the face of the games industry, but this satire is very relevant for consoles, which don't have mods, so console gamers rely upon the release of overpriced DLC to get new stuff in their game.  It's good for a laugh, the platforming is fairly easy and it can be quite entertaining, just don't buy it for full price.

DLC Quest is a simplistic satire game about DLC. Sadly this joke gets old after 15 minutes ad one would probably expect. After all transforming a joke into a game doesn't improve the quality of the joke; rather in this case, transform said joke into meaningless blabber that comes off as repetitive and obnoxious. Gameplay itself is lacklustre and generally shoddy. As for graphics, well retro graphics are no excuse for unimaginative and ugly design. We've seen many games use retro style successfully: Hotline Miami, Evoland, and Cave Story to name a few, yet DLC Quest fails to hit the mark. Perhaps the only redeemable aspect is it's chip-tune music.   Had I reviewed this game years ago upon first playing it, I would have given it a positive review, but upon looking back, a mixed-negative review is far more appropriate.

DLC Quest is a platformer where you collect coins to buy 'DLC' that can get you through the game. This game is pretty hilarious, since you need to buy DLC to do even the most basic things, like jumping and moving left.  For the most part, the platforming is pretty easy, and most people should get through the game with little challenge. The game's also fairly short too. I beat both campaigns with 100% completion in 2.5 hours. DLC Quest is pretty much entirely held up by it's humor. If you're familiar with video game culture in general, it will keep you laughing. You can even buy Horse Armor.  The graphics are basic pixel work, but it looks nice and it's appropriate for this style of platformer. The chiptune music is alright but not really memorable. The game thankfully controls pretty well, except that wall jumping may take some time to get used to.  DLC Quest is easy and very short, but it's funny and it only costs $3. It's definitely worth the minor investment.

DLC Quest shares a premise with earlier indie game Evoland (take an abstract concept of commentary on the video game industry and turn it into a game itself) and unfortunately suffers the same fatal flaw: abstract concepts of commentary on the video game industry make terrible game premises. DLC Quest, however, manages to be even WORSE in this regard, because its core premise has no progression even built in; it's literally one overextended joke about how much AAA publishers contempt for the consumer comes out in their handling of Downloadable Content for published titles, and in fact it's not even that sophisticated. Much as the game itself is only £2 (65p at time of writing) the fact is that without charging actual money for DLC the game loses any real investment a player could have in the satire it's peddling because there's an absence of the actual tangible effect of the relatable concept; but it can't do that because doing so would undermine its stated political standpoint. The idea was doomed from the start and in terms of realisation of that foretold failure DLC Quest, like Evoland before it, does not disappoint.

This is a weird game!  I don't often gravitate towards satirical games, as far as I know the only other game I've ever played that remotely fits the genre was Microshaft Winblows 98. Obviously that was Gates-bashing, and this is DLC-bashing; satire tends to reflect whatever the fashion of the public's disdain happens to be. For DLC Quest, their attempt to both mock and highlight the major game company's use of DLC to extract more money out of the end user is apt and well thought out.  The first part of the game is an outright taunt at the concept; starting with no ability to attack, animate, jump, even move left, you need to use the in-game coins to purchase any of these things as DLC. From there the basic abilities become available and thus establish the foundation of the game, you need to return to the seller to get more DLCs in order to progress. The more stages of the game you complete, the more DLCs you're likely to need to continue further. A second part becomes available when you complete the first game, which is designed to be more like an actual game, complete with a story, a collection of stock characters, a bad guy and indeed more DLCs. I have to give the guys credit for making a semi-coherant storyline and plot progression through this part of the game and the jokes are good, but the game brakes the fourth wall way too much, which I don't mind in the first part - it makes the most sence there.  4 out of 5. This is a weird game that I'd recommend to anyone who likes a quirky satire that's more interested in sending a message than looking good.

I have collected all awardments of this game (Not including the time ones) and suppose right now is the best time to write my review.  DLC Quest is a retro-style platformer that makes fun of the casual gimmicks of video games, as well as DLC, which is what this game is all about. You obviously don't need to pay real world money for the DLC. Instead you collect coins to use as in-game currency. You can also find hidden DLC packs to collect and then purchase to use. DLC can be toggled at the DLC purchase menu.  Off the subject of DLC, I would like to talk about how DLC Quest makes fun of generic video game mechanics. I loved how there was a DLC called 'Remove Ads' that replaces the Buy Soda signs, as they are in the form of adverts, even though they were never advertising anything real ever. Another funny moment is a place called 'Allan please add zone name' which starts off as a blank space past the Dark Zone, but getting the correct DLC for it makes it a real map with real everything, but keeps the name for some reason.  I loved DLC Quest, it was a quick and very easy game to play, and I enjoyed the comedic events that go along with it. I give this game 8/10.

I have collected all awardments of this game (Not including the time ones) and suppose right now is the best time to write my review.  DLC Quest is a retro-style platformer that makes fun of the casual gimmicks of video games, as well as DLC, which is what this game is all about. You obviously don't need to pay real world money for the DLC. Instead you collect coins to use as in-game currency. There can be DLC for almost anything, like controls, pause menu, and other things that don't need DLC at all. However most of the DLC is basically add-ons and things to progress through the story. You can also find hidden DLC packs to collect and then purchase to use. DLC can be toggled at the DLC purchase menu.  Off the subject of DLC, I would like to talk about how DLC Quest makes fun of generic video game mechanics. I loved how there was a DLC called 'Remove Ads' that replaces the Buy Soda signs, as they are in the form of adverts, even though they were never advertising anything real ever. Another funny moment is a place called 'Allan please add zone name' which starts off as a blank space past the Dark Zone, but getting the correct DLC for it makes it a real map with real everything, but keeps the name for some reason.  I loved DLC Quest, it was a quick and very easy game to play, and I enjoyed the comedic events that go along with it. I give this game 8/10.
